title: SurNamExp_usage
text: : SurNamExp packages clean surname dataset (last_names) interactive Shiny app quick exploration. Run fast: launch SurNamExp::launch_app() filter, rank, summarise names frequency. Data inside: last_names two columns — Surname (character) Per_1000_Americans (numeric). Reproducible pipeline: dataset built script data-raw/ can regenerate update . Well-documented: functions data use roxygen2 docs; vignette shows usage interpretation. Typical workflow: pick subset → view plot/table → read summary stats → export cite results. Design choice: keep Shiny UI thin; put reusable logic small helper functions clarity testing. Install hint: remotes::install_github(“https://github.com/ETC5523-2025/assignment-4-packages--shiny-apps-apan0085”, upgrade = “never”) launch_app().

title: Common Last Names in the USA
text: goal SurNamExp make surname frequency data easy explore communicate. packages clean dataset (last_names), Shiny app can launch launch_app(), reproducible data pipeline data-raw/. Clear roxygen2 docs vignette guide run app, interpret outputs, regenerate data.

title: Common Last Names in the USA
text: Shiny app inst/app/ simple filter → plot/table workflow. Packaged data: last_names (columns: Surname, Per_1000_Americans). Reproducibility: data prep script data-raw/ (e.g., make_last_names.R). Docs: roxygen reference, vignette, (optionally) pkgdown site.

title: Common Last Names in the USA
text: last_names tidy dataset common surnames approximate frequency per 1,000 people. Columns: Surname — character; family name (e.g., “Smith”, “Johnson”). Per_1000_Americans — numeric; estimated count per 1,000 people. See ?SurNamExp::last_names details.

title: Common Last Names in the USA
text: Launch app interactively browse name frequencies. Visualise rankings view summary statistics update selections. Recreate dataset via script data-raw/ full reproducibility.

title: last_names — last_names
code: # Inspect structure str(last_names) #> 'data.frame':	21 obs. of  2 variables: #>  $ Surname           : chr  "Smith" "Johnson" "Williams" "Brown" ... #>  $ Per_1000_Americans: num  8 6.3 5.3 4.7 4.7 4.1 3.8 3.7 3.7 3.6 ...  # Top 5 by frequency head(last_names[order(-last_names$Per_1000_Americans), ], 5) #>    Surname Per_1000_Americans #> 1    Smith                8.0 #> 2  Johnson                6.3 #> 3 Williams                5.3 #> 4    Brown                4.7 #> 5    Jones                4.7
